titlestmt.titleproper: Leach, W. Barton (Walter Barton), 1900 -1971. Papers, 1920-1971: Finding Aid.

titlepage.titleproper: Leach, W. Barton (Walter Barton), 1900 -1971. Papers, 1920-1971: Finding Aid.

did.head: Summary Information
did.repository: Harvard Law School Library, Harvard University
did.abstract: Contents of this collection relate to Leach's teaching career, professional activities, service in the Air Force during World War II, and involvement in national defense matters. Includes material relating to his role as consultant to the Air Force, 1946-1966, his work with Harvard University's Defense Policy Seminar, which he founded, and drafts of an incomplete autobiography.

acqinfo.p: The papers of Walter Barton Leach, professor of law, legal scholar, and consultant on military affairs to the U.S. Government and the Armed Services, were presented as a gift to the President and Fellows of Harvard College by Professor Leach's widow, Blanche C. Leach. The letter of gift, dated 24 October 1972, states that this gift "is intended for the use and benefit of the Harvard Law School".

accessrestrict.p: Access to these papers is governed by the rules and regulations of the Harvard Law School Library. This collection is open to the public, but is housed off-site at Harvard Depository and requires 2-day advance notice for retrieval. Consult the Special Collections staff for further information.

In addition, access is governed by the terms of access as set forth by Mrs. Blanche C. Leach in her letter of October 24, 1972, addressed to professor Morris L. Cohen, Librarian of the Harvard Law School Library (for copy see Case File).

userestrict.head: Copyright:
userestrict.p: Copyright for these papers has not passed into the public domain. Permission to publish is required.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Walter Barton Leach relate to his professional life and activities as law teacher and legal scholar (1930-1971); his service in the American Air Forces during World War II (1942-1945); his role as a consultant to the U.S. Air Force and the U.S. Department of the Air Force (1946-1966); his founding and work with the so-called Defense Policy Seminar, established at Harvard University in 1954; and his involvement in national defense matters beginning in the early 1950's. There are drafts of several sections of an autobiography which 4dBL had planned but which was not completed. The Leach Papers also include manuscripts of most of his published and unpublished speeches and occasional pieces such as anecdotes and poems.

The correspondence files of WBL include both letters received and carbons of letters sent. There is a complete file of carbons, the so-called "dictation file", in chronological order, covering the years 1958 through 1970; carbons are bound, each volume covering a six-months' period. Among Professor Leach's correspondents were:

list.item: John Fitzgerald Kennedy (President of the U.S.)
Nathan M. Pusey (President of Harvard University)

note.p: This collection is grouped into two contingencies. The first is arranged in eight series. The second is arranged into four of the initial given eight series.

Correspondence is mainly of a professional nature. Topics discussed in the letters include publications by WBL and by his correspondents, employment matters of former students, national defense matters in general way, studies at Harvard and other places in the field of military defense.

Correspondents include professional colleagues, persons in Massachusetts and national politics, Harvard alumni, news media editors, members of the armed services of the United States and Great Britain. Correspondence consists of letters received and carbons of letters sent. A substantial amount of correspondence is with various members of the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University, a division under the Graduate School of Public Administration. In 1954, WBL helped establish the Defense Policy Seminar at the Center, and he was instrumental in procuring many of the Seminar's guest lecturers such as Field Marshall Montgomery. Of interest are the folders relating to WBL's activity as an advisor to John F. Kennedy during the 1960 presidential election.

Important correspondents: U.S. Senators Joseph Clark, Edward Brooke and Stuart Symington, U.S. Supreme Court Justices Felix Frankfurter and John Harlan, Henry Kissinger, Sir John Slessor, Telford Taylor, and Barbara Tuchman.

This is a so-called "dictation file" of carbons of letters sent out by WBL. Carbons were bound in chronological order, each volume convering six months of a given year. The period covered is January 1, 1958 to December 31, 1970. In content, the series is similar to the unbound correspondence series.

This series relates primarily to courses on Property (conveyancing, wills, future interests, perpetuities) with some material on Evidence and Contracts. Boxes 19-24 contain loose-leaf books filled with notes and assignments. Boxes 25 and 26 contain unbound notes, correspondence with students, and material for a manual (never published) for law students.

This series relates to books, articles and speeches by WBL and to material on perpetuity reform throughout the world. It consists of notes, drafts, research material, final typewritten manuscripts and reprints of some of WBL's writings and speeches as well as correspondence about specific subjects or specific pieces of writing. A substantial part of this series deals with the three casebooks (on wills, property and future interests) put together by WBL, alone or in conjunction with others.

This series begins with books by WBL, arranged alphabetically by author or co-author. Speeches and articles are then arranged chronologically by date of publication or delivery. Research material on perpetuities reform is at the end, arranged alphabetically.

The major portion of the material in this series concerns matters relating to the Defense Policy Seminar which WBL helped establish at Harvard in 1954. Other groups of material deal with WBL's involvement in national defense matters beginning in the early 1950's, and with articles and speeches of WBL advocating a strong defense force. The material has been left in its original arrangement. Dates covered are 1951-1966.

This series consists of correspondence with colleagues, speeches at meetings of Harvard Clubs and Harvard Law School Associations throughout the country, and material relating to the Harvard Law Review, the Harvard Law School Model Trial, the Leach Club, and other Harvard University activities. Period covered is 1930-1970.

This series contains clippings, photographs, correspondence, and typewritten drafts for a proposed autobiography (unpublished) by WBL. There is a good deal of material relating to his activities in the United States Air Force; also a section on legal poetry. The series is arranged alphabetically.

Professor Leach's Air Force files consist chiefly of material relating to his service with the American Air Forces during World War II and subsequently with the United States Air Force, both active service and service after retirement. Files include his reports and memoranda relating to operations analysis; material relating to his work as a consultant; appointments and travel orders; correspondence concerning special missions; material relating to investigations of particular strategic weapons or aircraft; recommendations regarding the U.S. Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs and other Air Force schools.

The series contains a sizeable amount of correspondence with various staff officers. Among Professor Leach's major correspondents are: Harold Brown, James B. Conant, James H. Douglas, Jr., Thomas K. Finletter, Murray Green, Henry A. Kissinger, Laurence S. Kuter, Curtis S. Power, Donald A. Quarles, Stuart Symington, Nathan P. Twining, Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Eugene M. Zuckert.
All of this material is now de-classified.

chronitem.event: b. Boston, Massachusetts. s. Walter Barton and Grace Winifred (Wise) L.
LL.B., cum laude, Harvard Law School
Secretary to Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr., U.S. Supreme Court
Engaged in general practice of law in Boston, associated with the firm of Warner, Stackpole Bradlee
Instructor in law, Harvard Law School
Assistant professor of law, Harvard Law School
Professor of law, Harvard Law School
Story Professor of law, Harvard Law School
Professor, Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration
Served as private, Infantry, U.S. Army

list.item: Cases on Massachusetts Law of Evidence, 1935
Handbook of Massachusetts Evidence, 1940; the third edition (with John T. McNaughton), 1956; 4th edition with Paul J. Liacos, 1967)
Cases and Text on Property (with A. James Casner), 1950; second edition, (with A. James Casner), 1969
The Rule against, Perpetuities (England, with J.Ii.C. Morris), 1955
The Rule against Perpetuities (U.S., with Owen Tudor), 1957
Cases and Text on Future Interests and Estate Planning, 1961 (with J, K. Logan)
Also author of articles in legal and other periodicals
Co-author of American Law of Property, 1952

controlaccess.head: Additional Index Terms
controlaccess.p: The following catalog entries represent persons, organizations, and topics documented in this collection. An entry for each appears in the Harvard On Line Library Information System (HOLLIS) and other automated bibliographic databases. THIS IS NOT AN INDEX.
controlaccess.corpname: Montgomery of Alamein, Bernard Law Montgomery, Viscount,
controlaccess.subject: Law teachers

note.p: Within each series individual items or folders are identified by box and folder number. For example, the number 5-12 corresponds to box 5, folder 12.
Series Note

Correspondence is mainly of a professional nature. Topics discussed in the letters include publications by WBL and by his correspondents, employment matters of former students, national defense matters in a general way, studies at Harvard and other places in the field of military defense.
Correspondents are professional colleagues, persons in Massachusetts and national politics, Harvard alumni, news media editors, members of the armed services of the United States and Great Britain.

Correspondence consists of letters received and carbons of letters sent. A substantial amount of correspondence is with various members of the Center For International Affairs at Harvard University, a division under the Graduate School of Public Administration. In 1954 WBL helped establish the Defense Policy Seminar at the Center, and he was instrumental in procuring many of the Seminar's guest lecturers such as Field Marshal Montgomery. Of interest are the folders relating to WBL's activity as an advisor to John F. Kennedy during the 1960 presidential election.

Important correspondents: U.S. Senators Joseph Clark, Edward Brooke and Stuart Symington; U.S. Supreme Court Justices Felix Frankfurter and John Harlan; Henry Kissinger; Sir John Slessor; Telford Taylor; Barbara Tuchman.
Correspondence relates to WBL's listing in the Retired Professors Registry.
See also folder for Browder, Olin L., Jr., in GENERAL CORRESPONDENCE Series.

unittitle.corpname: Special Committee on Legal Services in the Department of Defense

note.p: File relates to cartoons of WBL by Andrews.
Mr. Berry was a student and teaching assistant of WBL; corr. relates to his positions with the Defense Dept. in Washington and a subsequent position as corporation attorney.
Professor Bowie served as Director of the Center For International Affairs, Graduate School of Public Administration, Harvard University. Corr. concerns the Defense Studies Program.
Professor Browder was Chairman of the American Bar Association Committee on the Rule Against Perpetuities. WBL was a member of this Committee. File contains a copy of Perpetuity Legislation Handbook.
File relates to The Report of the Cox Commission on the troubles at Columbia in 1968.

did.unittitle: Cutter, R. Ammi, Justice, Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court 1957-1968

item.persname: Cass, Leo M. (son of Dr. Leo J. Cass)
Cass, Victoria B. (daughter of Dr. Leo J. Cass)

item.corpname: U.S. Court of Appeals, Second Circuit

list.item: File contains photograph of Rufus Choate.

note.p: File contains a copy of the proofs of an article by Professor Davis on "Letting the Conduct of Affected Parties Play a Meaningful Role in Resolving Disputes Between Adjoining and Concurrent Owners of Real Property."
File contains some amusing bumper stickers re perpetuity legislation. For further correspondence see WRITINGS AND RESEARCH: Perpetuities Reform-California and Perpetuities Reform-Kentucky.
For more correspondence re Trevor Dupuy see GENERAL CORRESPONDENCE (UNBOUND): Historical Evaluation and Research Organization (HERO) 1956-1971
For letters of WBL addressed to Herbert B. Ehrmann, see the HERBERT B. EHRMANN PAPERS in the Harvard Law School Library.
Mr. Fitzgerald was a student of WBL; file relates to his third-year paper.

did.unittitle: Frankfurter, Felix, Justice, U.S. Supreme Court 1954-1962

note.p: File contains correspondence with others after Frankfurter's death. For letters of WBL to Frankfurter see Library of Congress, Register of Felix Frankfurter papers. For additonal correspondence see GENERAL CORRESPONDENCE (UNBOUND): Shakespeare-Oxford Society.
Includes copy of typed manuscript "Climbing the Family Tree" by his father, Judge Herbert F. Goodrich of the U.S. Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.

item.corpname: George Washington University, The Law School

did.unittitle: Harlan, John Marshall, Justice, U.S. Supreme Court 1958-1970

note.p: File relates to numerous studies done by HERO on such things as the:

item.title: "Documentary History of the Armed Forces of the United States".

list.item: Copy of "A Proposal to Develop a Total Information System Responsive to the Needs of the Congress of the United States";
Article, "Responding to Disarmament Violations"by Roger Fisher;
Article, "Burma and Its Army: A Contrast in Motivations and Characteristics".

item.corpname: Hall of Fame for Great Americans

did.unittitle: Kennedy, John Fitzgerald (President of the United States) 1959-1966

note.p: File relates to WBL's activities as advisor to JFK on defense and military policies during 1959 and 1960. Contains correspondence between the two and memoranda such as "The Unstable Balance of Terror" and "Aspects of Defense Policy for Emphasis".

File contains correspondence and a Christmas card from Kissinger to WBL. Also a copy of "The Unsolved Problems of European Defense" by Henry Kissinger and "The Ceylonese Press and the Fall of the Sirimavo Bandaranaike Government" by Raymond E. Vickery, Jr. Much of the early correspondence concerns the Center for International Affairs at Harvard, of which Kissinger was Associate Director and later on Director.
File contains correspondence and a statement by the Cuban Judiciary Association (in exile).

did.unittitle: Leach, Walter Barton: Letters Not Sent 1967

note.p: File relates to WBL's work as a member of the editorial board for Little, Brown's Law Book Department. There is a great deal of correspondence re Professor David Mellinkoff's book Language of the Law and re the possibility of Mellinkoff dditing a legal dictionary. For correspondence with Little, Brown Company re WBL's books, see WRITINGS AND RESEARCH. File contains a copy of the Law School Adoption Report for Little, Brown Company for 1969.

did.unittitle: Logan, James K. (Dean of the University of Kansas Law School) 1960-1971

note.p: For further correspondence with Dean Logan, see WRITINGS AND RESEARCH: Property Law Indicted; Leach and Logan, Cases and Text on Future Interests and Estate Planning, Correspondence ; Leach, Cases and Text on the Law of Wills, 2nd Edition, Correspondence.
File relates to admission of Professor Lusky's son to Harvard College.
File relates to speech given by WBL at the McGill Law Banquet 1961.
Mr. Megarry was an English barrister and later a judge in the Royal Courts of Justice, London.

For further correspondence re Professor Mellinkoff see GENERAL CORRESPONDENCE (UNBOUND): Little, Brown Company, where both Mellinkoff's book Language of the Law and the proposal that he edit a legal dictionary are discussed.
File includes typed carbon of WBL's review of Montgomery's Memoirs, published in November 1958.
Mr. Morris was Professor of Law, Madgalen College, Oxford University, England. Morris and WBL were co-authors of The Rule Against Perpetuities, (1956).

item.corpname: Ohio State University, National Security Policy Seminar

note.p: Mr. Pace was Chairman of the Board, General Dynamics Corporation; formerly Secretary of the Army.
Mr. Parry was a professor at Downing College, Cambridge University, England. Folder includes essay by Parry entitled "The British Consular Conventions" (Essays in honor of Lord McNair).
File includes correspondence with John G. Powers, President, and contains a copy of "The Prentice-Hall Attorneys' Wills Kit".

unittitle.persname: Price, Don K. (Dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration)

did.unittitle: Pusey, Nathan M. (President of Harvard University) 1958-1970

note.p: Putnam is an artist and a childhood friend of WBL's.
File contains a copy of paper by Ross, "Restrictions on Disinheritance of Illegitimate Ninor Children in California, Florida, Missouri, Nebraska and Washington".

item.corpname: The Roscoe Pound-American Trial Lawyers Foundation

note.p: Mr. Sallagar was on the staff of the Rand Corporation for which he wrote a study entitled "The Road to Total War: Escalation in World War II".
Mr. Saltonstall was a member of the Boston City Council.
File includes photographs of Senator Saltonstall lecturing to the Defense Policy Seminar in December 1975.
See also GENERAL CORRESPONDENCE (UNBOUND): Schenk, Peter J.
File contains a program for the Institute on Wills and Probate, March 8,9, 1962 at the Southwestern Legal Center in Dallas, Texas.
File contains a copy of Professor Schwartz' pamphlet, Future Interests and Estate Planning; also a typed carbon of WBL's forword to a book on future interests by Professor Schwartz.

unittitle.persname: Scott, Robert L., Jr. (Gerneal, USAF, Retired)

note.p: File relates to the dispute over the "true" author of Shakespeare's works. It contains a copy of "Edward de Vere, The Seventeenth Earl of Oxford: The Real Shakespeare" by William Kent and others.

did.unittitle:
Simes, Lewis M. (Professor of Law, University of Michigan, later Hastings)
1957-1961

unittitle.persname: Slessor, Sir John C. (Marshall of the Royal Air Force)
Slessor, J.A.F. (son of Sir John Slessor)

note.p: File relates to equipment purchased by WBL.
File is primarily concerned with attempt in 1960 and 1961 to have Mr. Sundlun appointed as Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency or for an Air Force Secretariat position.

File relates mostly to Senator Symington's attempts to unify the three military services and to the possibility of his candidacy for President in 1960. File contains mostly correspondence although there are also press releases and several reports relating to the unification problem; also an address by Senator Symington given in 1955, entitled "The Silent Curtain". Senator Symington was a member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Armed Services and also a member of the Committee on Aeronautical and Space Sciences.

unittitle.corpname: University of California, School of Law
The University of Georgia, School of Law

note.p: File relates to a series of lectures WBL was prevented from giving by the severe injury to his hip.

item.corpname: United States Army Artillery and Missile School
University of Colorado, School of Law

note.p: File contains a draft and a finished copy of "Survival In an Age of Technological Contest".

did.unittitle: Wilkins, Raymond S., Chief Justice, Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, 1959-1961

note.p: File contains copies of a report to the American Bar Association on "The Improvement of Conveyancing and Recording Practices" and drafts for an Act in Massachusetts, "To Protect Land Titles From Uncertain and Obsolete Restrictions".

did.unittitle: Wyzanski, Charles E., Jr., Chief Justice, United States District Court, 1965-1966

note.p: File contains a xeroxed copy of a rough draft of "Trial and Error: Reflections of a United States District Judge".
Series Note

This is a so-called "dictation file" of carbons of letters sent out by WBL. Carbons were bound in chronological order, each volume covering six months of a given year. The period covered is January 1, 1958 to December 31, 1970. In content, the series is similar to the unbound correspondence series.
Series Note

This Series relates primarily to courses on Property (conveyancing, wills, future interests, perpetuities) with some material on Evidence and Contracts. Boxes 19 to 24 contain looseleaf books filled with notes and assignments. Boxes 25 and 26 contain unbound notes, correspondence with students and material for a manual (never published) for law students.
File relates to 1L students who were WBL's advisees during spring semester 1968.
File contains notes, correspondence, grade sheets, examination questions and communications from WBL to his classes.
File relates to proposed book by WBL on legal education which was never written.
25-5 to 25-7 contain correspondence.
25-8 to 26-2 contain notes, memoranda, newspaper articles and other articles bearing on legal education.
26-3 to 26-5 contain transcripts of speeches made at the Second Annual School for Young Lawyers, Harvard Law School Forum, November 10,11, 1949.
File contains notes, correspondence, grade sheets, examination questions and various communications from WBL to his classes.
See: WRITINGS AND RESEARCH: Zimmerman v. Shreeve
Series Note

This Series relates to books, articles and speeches by WBL and to material on perpetuity reform throughout the world. It consists of notes, drafts, research material, final typewritten manuscripts and reprints of some of WBL's writings and speeches as well as correspondence about specific subjects or specific pieces of writing. A substantial part of this Series deals with the three casebooks (on wills, property and future interests) put together by WBL, alone or in conjunction with others.

This Series begins with books by WBL, arranged alphabetically by author or co-author. Speeches and articles are then arranged chronologically by date of publication or delivery. Research material on perpetuities reform is at the end, arranged alphabetically.

File contains correspondence and a reprint of a review of the book by
Cecil A. Wright (Dean, Faculty of Law, University of Toronto) in the Canadian Bar Review, 1956. The 2nd Edition of Leach and Morris appeared in 1962. J.H.C. Morris was Professor of Law, Oxford University, England.

note.p: File relates to work by WBL and Mr. Owen Tudor which was Part 24 of the American Law of Property.

30-11 contains correspondence re Leach and Tudor and re its 1962 Supplement. Under September 22, 1958 there is a reprint of a review of the book in the Washington University Law Quarterly by John E. Howe (Professor of Law, St. Louis University). There are also carbon drafts of various sections of the work and proof sheets of Parts 23 and 24 of ALP.
30-12 contains proof sheets and carbon drafts. For other proof sheets see WRITINGS AND RESEARCH: Carter v. Berry.

Series Note

The major portion of the material in this Series concerns matters relating to the Defense Policy Seminar which WBL helped establish at Harvard in 1954. Other groups of material deal with WBL's involvement in national defense matters beginning in the early 1950's, and with articles and speeches of WBL advocating a strong defense force.
The material has been left in its original arrangement. Dates covered are 1951 to 1966.

note.p: Series Note

This Series consists of correspondence with colleagues, speeches at meetings of Harvard Clubs and Harvard Law School Associations throughout the country, and material relating to the Harvard Law Review, the Harvard Law School Model Trial, the Leach Club and other Harvard University activities. Period covered is 1930-1970.

Series Note

This Series contains clippings, photographs, correspondence, and typewritten drafts for a proposed autobiography (unpublished) by WBL. There is a good deal of material relating to his activities in the United States Air Force; also a section on legal poetry.
The Series is arranged alphabetically.
File relates to proposal to award Master's Degrees at the Air Force Academy.

49-2 is a looseleaf notebook.

Clippings are about WBL, the Defense Policy Seminar and other subjects related to WBL's professional or military activities. All clippings had been intended for a scrapbook which was never assembled. Clippings have not been arranged in any kind of order. Clippings are mainly from the 1955-1957 period.

did.unittitle: Clipping, correspondence (copy of letter from Erwin Griswold to Stuart Symington), article The Stupidity of a Big Navy by Leach.

note.p: Series Note

Professor Leach's Air Force files consist chiefly of material relating to his service with the American Air Forces during World War II and subsequently with the United States Air Force, both active service and service after retirement. Files include his reports and memoranda relating to operations analysis; material relating to his work as a consultant; appointments and travel orders; correspondence concerning special missions; material relating to investigations of particular strategic weapons or aircraft; recommendations regarding the U.S. Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs and other Air Force schools.
All of this material is now de-classified (see letter in W.B. Leach, CASE FILE, at Curator's Desk).
